info.game_comments:
2000-B College Championship semifinal game 1.  
From the University of Washington in Seattle.

(1, 1).clue: The promised land of Canaan was said to be flowing with these 2 things

(3, 1).clue: Uh-oh!  This 14,410-foot mountain that looms over Seattle is actually an active volcano

(4, 1).clue: Cut from cords of semolina dough, they're dried & packed in boxes with cheese by Kraft

(5, 1).clue: This ancient statue is also named the Aphrodite of Melos

(6, 1).clue: One who goes along for the ride

(1, 2).clue: Sound the trumpets!  Before his death, Moses named this man his successor

(3, 2).clue: When dining at SkyCity, this famous tower's revolving restaurant, save room for the Lunar Orbiter dessert

(4, 2).clue: Billabong, an Aussie company, makes this out of emu, ostrich & kangaroo meats as well as regular beef

(5, 2).clue: He said he had no difficulty expressing sadness & extreme solitude in the work seen here

(6, 2).clue: To study in minute detail or take apart; some people draw the line at doing it to frogs

(1, 3).clue: They're the only 2 books of the Hebrew bible named for specific women

(3, 3).clue: A museum on Main Street is named for this Klondike event that turned 1890s Seattle into a boom town

(4, 3).clue: Cut in sections off trees, it's boiled, scraped & then dried for commercial use, like for bottle stoppers

(5, 3).clue: A 231-foot band of linen, this medieval embroidery depicts the Norman Conquest of England

(6, 3).clue: It's the highest rank of diplomat

(1, 4).clue: While in the court of Nebuchadnezzar, this visionary was given the name Belteshazzar

(3, 4).clue: Known as the EMP for short, this music museum seen here is one of Seattle's newest attractions

(4, 4).clue: Cut down a bunch of Thompson seedlesses, dry them & you get these

(5, 4).clue: This movement got its name from the painting seen here

(6, 4).clue: The pressure is on to make this coffee, quick

(1, 5).clue: Twice, with an evil spirit upon him, this king tried to slay David with his javelin

(3, 5).clue: Dudley, who lives in the Seattle Aquarium, aspires to the largest of these 8-armed creatures in captivity

(4, 5).clue: Cut from a bog, it's then dried for use as a fuel

(5, 5).clue: She vacationed in New Mexico & settled there after her husband Alfred Stieglitz died in 1946

(6, 5).clue: The name of this thin, sheer fabric preceded condor & albatross in the names of pedal-driven planes

(1, 1).clue: Mary McAleese is president of this country also called Eire

(2, 1).clue: Greeks in your dorm might be from Athens or members of one of these organizations

(3, 1).clue: The off-Broadway hit "The Bomb-itty of Errors" is a hip-hop version of this Shakespeare play

(5, 1).clue: Each human cell has 23 pairs of chromosomes, 1 of them this type rated XX or XY

(6, 1).clue: Biblical book that's the source of the Jewish Theological Seminary's "And The Bush Was Not Consumed"

(1, 2).clue: In 1999 Vaira Vike-Freiberga became president of this Baltic nation wedged between Lithuania & Estonia

(2, 2).clue: As seen in the film "Dead Man on Campus", legend has it that if this person dies you get straight As

(3, 2).clue: "Ataka", perhaps the most famous play in this form of Japanese drama, has been adapted for Kabuki

(4, 2).clue: Dyan Cannon plays Judge Cone, she of the sexy Wattles, on this TV show

(5, 2).clue: Beadle & Tatum's study of mold on this food helped launch molecular genetics

(6, 2).clue: "Petimus Credimus", "We Seek, We Trust" at this Christian school in the news when George W. visited in 2000

(1, 3).clue: The daughter of 2 former leaders, Chandrika Kumaratunga is president of this country highlighted here

(2, 3).clue: By now you may have personal names for some of these dorm insects, AKA Periplaneta Americana

(3, 3).clue: (Hi, I'm Donny Osmond.)  I sang "Any Dream Will Do" from "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat" at this composer's 50th birthday celebration in London in 1998

(4, 3).clue: He's passed for "astronomical" yardage quarterbacking Houston, Minnesota & Seattle

(5, 3).clue: Made up of amino acids, they form structures called histones around which DNA curls

(6, 3).clue: Honor & Country come after this in West Point's motto

(1, 4).clue: Since 1996 prime minister Sheikh Hasina has led this nation formerly known as East Pakistan

(2, 4).clue: You're all set to meet the Swedish students moving in across the hall with records like "Dancing Queen" by this band

(3, 4).clue: In a play by Karl Schonherr, a man who plays this role in a passion play becomes a betrayer in real life, too

(4, 4).clue: Nickname of Katherine Kelley, author of tell-all-&-then-some bios of Nancy Reagan & Jackie O.

(5, 4).clue: A key to mapping the human genome was the random-sequencing method known by the name of this weapon

(6, 4).clue: Yale's "Lux et Veritas" means "Light and" this

(1, 5).clue: In 2000 Tarja Halonen became the first woman president of this northern European nation seen here

(2, 5).clue: Stanton, Thompson, Leblanc & Marchand are all dorm names at my alma mater, this university in Canada's capital

(4, 5).clue: He represented Washington in the House for 30 years, including 1989-1995 as speaker

(5, 5).clue: The genotype is an organism's genetic makeup; this rhyming word means its resulting appearance

(6, 5).clue: The University of North Dakota's "Lux et Lex" means "Light and" this

(0, 0).clue: The only palaces on U.S. soil that were built for monarchs are found in this state
